misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that each distinct input value provided by the user (the 5 integers) requires its own unique variable identifier in the source code to be correctly stored and checked, rather than using a single variable that is overwritten within a loop.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student lacks a mental model of iterative variable reuse. While they understand that an accumulator variable (sumOfEvenNumbers) can be updated, they do not realize that the input variable (firstInputValue, secondInputValue, etc.) is a temporary storage location that can be reused to process a stream of data using a loop construct.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The code manifests as manual loop unrolling, with five separate variable declarations and five identical blocks of conditional logic, resulting in redundant and non-scalable code.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that processing a finite set of inputs (like the 5 integers requested) requires an explicit, one-to-one mapping between each input value and a unique variable name, alongside a duplicated sequence of logic, rather than utilizing a repeating control structure.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to recognize that the notional machine can reuse a single set of instructions (a loop) and a single memory location (a variable) to process multiple data points sequentially. Their model of execution is strictly linear and tied to the quantity of data.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Redundant code and poor scalability; the solution is manually expanded to fit the specific number of inputs instead of being abstracted.
